title: Isn't New Sion's health scaling passive on Soul Furnice pointless?
body:
Sion's base health at lv 18 has been reduced to 1680, from 2275: it now takes 298 CS to equal his original health before the rework, and that's not taking into account the fact that old Sion was also scaling his health on top of that base level. Riot might as well have just left his base health alone and taken away the health scaling passive all together.

If you make a character have a bonus "strength" in an area, but then put them so far behind the average in that area to the point that you need the bonus just to get up to par, that is not a bonus at all - it is a non-ability.

This isn't about his kit - his new kit actually looks pretty interesting to me, although the shifting of his old ult to his passive is a huge nerf if you liked AD carry Sion. 

This is about this weird thing I've noticed with several new champions and champion changes where they basically are given non-abilities. For example
-Azir has a passive which gives him attack speed for cooldown reduction; Azir has the 2nd lowest attack speed in the game
-The Soraka rework *sigh* gives her a move speed bonus passive, but lowers her base move speed
-The Cass rework gave her a passive for scaling cooldown reduction and bonus AP, but lowered the damage on her abilities and upped her cooldowns

This is about Anti-abilities; abilities which don't give you anything, because to compensate for you having the ability, you're worse at that thing than almost every other champ in the game. That's what I take issue to.

The reason they lowered his base HP/lvl for Soul Furnace's bonus HP gain is simple - it allows them to better differentiate the worst and best cases.

Imagine if Sion still had his old 104 HP/level. That would mean, he'd be pretty tanky even if he did not kill any creeps at all. However, if he killed anything, his HP amount would be skyrocketing to levels that are incredibly hard to deal with, especially in the early stages of the game. That means, the gain from Soul Furnace's passive would have to be incredibly small (like, 1 HP per creep, without a bonus for bigger creeps).

To accomodate that best case, they lowered his base gain significantly. Now, if he has an average or sub-average game, he'll only get as much tankiness as the next bruiser or tank (HP/lvl in the range of 85-100). However, if he has a significantly better game, he'll still get to be a total brick wall.

For numbers:
- Sion will get a comfortable amount of HP with 10 CS/lvl, as a laner.
- As a jungler, you need to do 2 camps/lvl, as camps give, on average, 12 HP.
- If you do 3 camps/lvl, you exceed the old HP/lvl gain.

Except that old Sion *did* have the original 104 HP/level, higher base health and the "Soul Furnace" (Enrage) passive. And no, it didn't really help him snowball at all.

The OP is completely on the ball, it's a non-ability at best and an active handicap at worst.

Except old {{champion:14}} 's kit was balanced around his old kit, which included not only his health gain but also his other abilities. Old Sion was balanced around being able to stack tons of health on top of his ultra-high bases, along with his point-and-click stun, magey shield and overwhelming ultimate steroid, and paid a high price for it (super-high mana costs, extreme kiteability, an inability to put his kit to full use). New Sion not only functions better as a whole, and can do a ton of things old Sion never could (initiate, travel across the map, stunlock the entire enemy team at once, etc.), but also scales a lot better with health thanks to his new shield. If Sion was somehow too squishy, then perhaps that would warrant an increase to his base health, but as it stands Sion looks like he can be extremely tanky despite his low health gain per level.
+1 for pointing out that he has a lot more tools now (or so it seems from looking at the kit)  and that they can buff him if need be.

Okay so, lets look at the ability, it gives 2 health for killing a small minion, but 8 for killing a large minion/monster or getting a kill or assist.  So if you use the jungle to calculate:

In the jungle on a 1 minute cooldown there are 4 large creatures, and 6 small creatures, so that gets him 44 health per jungle clear.  
4 x 8 = 32
6 x 2 = 12
32 + 12 = 44

BigWraith + Wolves + Wraiths + Golems = 10cs

If he is jungling he will get blue and red each 5 minutes, so as a jungle he gets 244 health in 5 minutes (with perfect clear) from 56 cs.  The aim of getting 595 health on his soul furnace should therefore only take 

44 x 5 + 2 x 8 + 2 x 4 = 220 + 16 + 8 = 244 health

10 x 5 + 6 = 56 cs

This means with perfect clear it will take in 12.2 minutes (132 cs), assuming no kills, and no lane tax (both unlikely).  Now you might say, "he would get counter-jungled" or "His clear is slower than that" so lets handle that, I would put in a factor of 25% loss, so that's an extra 3 minutes or so, to make it 15.24 minutes (However, this won't increase his cs since he won't be getting the health from those lost monsters).  Most games take longer than 15 minutes, 20-30 minutes, which means in that time (give lane tax and kills/assists) he will easily surpass his old base.

"But wait" you say, "old sion also scaled his health from kills, you have you calculate that to.".  Alright, I'll do that, old Sion, if he starts the game with his Enrage maxed then he gets 3 health per minion kill.

This means that with the 132 cs he would have 396 health, way less than the 595 of the new Sion, "but how long until new Sion's max health is more than old Sion's"?

Alright overly curious imaginary questioner, lets figure that out to. For each set of 5 minutes in the jungle new Sion gets 244, while old Sion got  168 (assuming his enrage was maxed from level 1, instead of level 13 or later).

However, if we are going to do this, we should take into account the lower early health scaling from old Sion, to do this I have used a random ap sion build guide (since Commando Yi was talking about AP Yi), this guide doesn't level his enrage until level 4 (so he doesn't get any health from his first clear) and maxes it at level 18, so I am going to say at 25 minutes the sion will be level 18 (way earlier than is true almost always).

Calculating this gives it that after 15 minutes new Sion in-fact has 7 more health than old Sion did, of course this is after the jungle first spawns.

Edit: Alright, I just had a look at an ad Sion build which maxes Enrage first, assuming you do that we will treat it as a transition from 1 to 3 per cs at 15 minutes, (So I am giving him the full 15 minute clear at 3 health per cs).  This gives old Sion more health until 20 minutes in, so this gets old sion with more health for 5 extra minutes, I don't think that's enough to win a game.

Old Sion had a total damage potential  of 600 base magic damage + a 1.8 ap ratio, half of it being AoE. Add in a few auto attacks with + 65 damage and it's still not the most impressive base damage by a long shot.

New Sion has a total damage potential of 1655 with a total  of a 2.6 AD ratio and 1.0 AP ratio on his kit PLUS 14%  *of enemies max health* as magic damage, and ALL of this can hit multiple targets. This is his maximum damage potential, and while it is harder to achieve than old sion's down-syndrome-level kit complexity, the fact is that the potential is much much higher.

I'd say the rework was performed just fine. Sion's a tanky brute with a huge damage Q nuke paired with AoE CC, they had to compensate on his newly given power by shaving off some tanky, but giving it back with effort out of his W's passive. Overall, everything about this Sion is better as a whole. AD sion is no longer just a stun and hit two trick pony, AP sion is no longer trapped with a crappy ult that only benefitted from AP once he got a lichbane and even then only benefitted for about two swings until it ended.

His new kit is a proper approach to him, while eliminating two half-efficient builds at the same time and making him way more reliable and competitive.

I don't see how you can compare ad nautilus at all to Sion's current form.

For one, he has two abilities that scale with AD and both deal AoE damage and crowd control whereas nautilus has 0. For two, he also has a health scaling W that deals damage based on enemy max HP, also in AoE, and while Naut also has a scaling shield, the damage scaling is strictly worse.

Nautilus serves a whole different class function and with horrible (read:nonexistant) scaling with AD items beyond his autoattack there's not even a minute comparison to current sion.

His Passive needs maybe a buff to move speed, also a fix against grievous wounds messing it up.

His Q is more than useful, an AoE ad nuke that slows on a low cooldown at worst, or an AoE ad blast that knocks up -and- stuns at best hitting for over 600 damage to all targets.

His Ult has a few negligible drawbacks, but we can chalk that up to player skill and wanting appropriate counterplay. He -cannot- be CC'd in that ult, and seeing as fights will typically happen at key points like the lanes, dragon, or baron, he has more than enough clearance to engage and do something. If the enemy has to worry about positioning against sion's ult, that's one more thing they're distracted with that can also cause them to slip up. Not to mention his W damage paired with the hit on it.

We don't want a Sion perfectly hitting his Q and R 100% of the time or else he'd be possibly the most bs champ in the entire game, so there's player-skill related caps to make them less reliable if not used properly but highly rewarding and game changing if they are.

I'd say the only thing Sion needs are a few QoL buffs like hitting broken towers with his ult and grievous wounds completely shutting down his passive when applied and he does. That's it.

The reason Riot gives champions abilities like that while making their base stats related to it relatively low is so that champion can scale more or less evenly throughout the game, so you feel some sense of progression as the game goes on longer (feeling useless late game sucks yo). 

Take {{champion:222}} for example. Her base attack speed is horrendous, being the 4th lowest in the game at lv 18. However, Pow-Pow helps mitigate that (as a "non-ability" as you put it), increasing her attack speed incrementally. With all 3 stacks, she has the highest base AS in the game at 1.6813 AS, compared to {{champion:22}} and {{champion:67}} tied for second at 1.105 AS. 

Switch to Fishbones though and her attack speed goes back to a measly 0.731 AS. That's the tradeoff, and that's why these kinds of abilities are in place, mitigating supposed weak points.

It should be considered however that Riot isn't perfect, and some might scale too hard or not hard enough into the mid/late game. But hey, thats what patches are for. :)

The thing is, Jinx gets a choice for either a horrible AS for range and AoE damage, or a lot of AS for shorter range.

Sion has no choice, Azir has no choice, Soraka has no choice

This is true. Some would say this is what makes Jinx not only strong, but OP, due to the fact that she has more leeway and options at her disposal. The reason I think she hasn't seen any significant nerfs to this (yet) may be because (at least in high level competitive play) she isnt able to use this advantage of hers to overcome her weaknesses in lane to other ADC's like {{champion:236}}  or really deal with the assassination abilities of someone like {{champion:29}}  later in the game.

So if someone like her, who HAS choices with nice tradeoffs, isn't strong enough to be a popular "meta" pick atm, it becomes clear that those WITHOUT choices (or at least less choices) would have an even tougher time. That kind of has been the always-dominant "gateway" champs needed to pass in order to be viable, the amount of choices they have. Thats why champs like {{champion:64}} , {{champion:412}}  and {{champion:60}}  have almost perpetually remained not only relevant, but dominant in the meta.
